text: The camera is stationary as the fade comes in: through a tangle of brush can be seen in the night, four dark figures, one of them carrying a lantern. They are evidently searching for something. They come toward camera through a garden long neglected ... gone into ruin As they reach foreground the camera moves with them. They are men of the English servant class: a gardener and some hostlers. The gardener; who carries the lantern searches the ground ahead of them as they stumble forward, frightened. It isn't a job that they relish.

A Newcomb shot of the house of the English country type i a state of decay quite as sad as that of the garden. Windows are broken, shutters loose; it is bleak, desolate The dim figures of the men with their lantern are approaching from b. g. a corner of the house.
The men coming into scene, stop suddenly, startled.

CLOSEUP, a shutter hanging loose on rusty hinges, banging back and forth in a gust of wind. BACK TO SCENE: The men as they shudder. One of them tryin to conquer the fear that holds them, points up, telling them it was only a shutter in the wind. The gardener with the lantern indicates for them to press forward. They sta around the corner of the house. 2.

Around corner, lying crumpled, still and lifeless in f.g. is the body of a man. The men come around the corner with the lantern. They stop short in horror. The man with the lantern leans over the body. The others huddle with scare faces around him.  3.

The men, with the body below frame line. The gardener, holding the lantern so that he can see, looks down and ou of scene as though at the face of the dead man. He looks at the others and says in an awed whisper:
"It's ‘im. It's 'arry Balfour" BACK TO SCENE: The men look at each other in awe. One of them shakes his head slowly and says:
"This'll break 'is sister Lucy's 'eart" BACK TO SCENE. There is solemn assent to this.
"And 'ow about Sir James? Him as loved 'em both like they was 'is own children." BACK TO SCENE: Again there is solemn assent.

A Newcomb shot of another English country house, this one with lighted windows and well-kept grounds, a distinct contrast to the ruin just seen. Run only a few feet for swift, impressionistic effect and

Again the sense of contrast. Here are warmth, wealth, comfort. Seated at a piano is Lucy Balfour, a pretty Engl girl in her early twenties. Standing listening to her, as she plays, is Sir James Hamlin, a dignified, kindly count gentleman in his late forties.

Lucy and Sir James, as she finishes playing and looks up him with a wistful smile. He indicates for her to play something more. She selected a piece and is startled when little worried look crosses her face and she looks up at him and says:
"I simply can't understand, Sir James, why Harry went away without saying anything."
Lucy as she finishes title, a pretty puzzlement in her expression. It is apparent that she is not greatly worrie just perplexed. 6.
Sir James, as he smiles down at her gravely, a deep affection in his eyes, and says:
“There is nothing to worry about, Lucy, my dear."

The two at the piano, as Sir James finishes reaching over and patting Lucy's hand affectionately. After a moment sh resumes her playing. He stands watching her, then turns thoughtfully and goes out of scene. 8.
By arched entrance to hall, as Sir James comes thoughtful in and pulls a long bell-cord. A butler enters. With a lo off toward Lucy, Sir James gives a quiet order to the butler.

"Have my secretary come here." BACK TO SCENE: The butler exits. Sir James looks again of toward Lucy. In a moment his secretary enters -- a young man of the serious type, a student. Sir James asks him quietly:

"Any word, Mr. Hibbs?" BACK TO SCENE: Hibbs is about to answer, but looks off toward Lucy and then gets over in pantomime that perhaps they had better step into the hall. Sir James nods. They exit.  9.
Other side of doorway as Sir James and Hibbs come in. Now Hibbs tells him earnestly:

"I insisted, sir, on their searching the grounds over at the old Balfour place--" BACK TO SCENE: Sir James nods gravely to this, indicating that the secretary acted wisely, that that was the right thing to do. Hibbs goes on.
“Weird things have happened there in the last five years-- ever since Miss Lucy's father--" BACK TO SCENE: Sir James checks him with a gesture. Both look off sharply down the hall. 10
A maid, Miss Smithson, is standing at an open door, stari out and down in horror. She screams, drawing back. 11
Sir James and Hibbs, staring. They run out. 12
Lucy. She stops playing, listens in sudden fright, then rises and exits. 13

At door, Sir James, Hibbs, Miss Smithson, the gardener an a hostler. The gardener and the hostler are just straightening up from having placed below frames line in f.g. the body of the dead Harry Balfour. Sir James, leani over, straightens up gravely. The body is not seen. 14
At entrance to music room, as Lucy comes through, looks o screams and starts forward. 15

At door, as before, as Lucy comes in from down the hall, staring in horror at the body out of scene. “Harry! Harry she cries. Sir James put an arm about her comfortingly fo  a moment, leading her away a little, indicating for the maid to take her away. Miss Smithson leads Lucy out of scene. Sir James turns and gives an order to the butler, who exits quickly. Sir James turns to the hostler and others and gives orders. Hibbs, looking off after Lucy, exits in that direction. Sir James starts quickly up the stairs. 16
Lucy, on a couch, being comforted by the maid. Hibbs come slowly in, standing for a moment looking at them. At a gesture from Hibbs, the maid quickly withdraws. Hibbs sit on the couch beside Lucy. 17

Hibbs and Lucy, as he sits on the couch beside her. She i staring off with tragic face. Hibbs feels terribly about all. He would like to be able to speak a consoling word t her, but he does not know just what to say or how to say Hesitatingly, he says:

"Miss Balfour, I----- " BACK TO SCENE: She turns away to the end of the couch and bursts into uncontrollable sobbing. Hibbs sits and looks her with the deepest sympathy and a sort of pathetic helplessness.

CLOSE UP (NIGHT) a broken shutter with broken window pane. A bat fluttering against the pane. The shutter bangs in a gust of wind.

Two men are seen dimly, standing under a tree. A jaunting cart is driving slowly in, with the gardener and Miss Smithson. The cart stops as they look off towards the house. (The cart is loaded with trunks, baggage.)

Grand Staircases. Coming down the stairs are two figures, man and a woman. The man, who carries a lamp, is as stran a creature as the eyes ever beheld. He wears a black beav hat and a black Inverness coat and his face has on it the pallor of death. There is, indeed, something not of this Earth in his appearance. Nor is the woman with him less strange. Her face also is of an unearthly pallor. She is garbed all in black, with long black sleeves to her cloak that look like wings. They come the long walk down the stairs. He hands the lamp to the woman. No word is spoken between them. She starts off toward a side room. The man goes slowly toward the front door.

The jaunting cart in f.g., the two men at side under a tr A light passes a downstairs window. The Man in the Beaver Hat comes out the front door. The gardener suddenly whips his steed and the cart goes out of scene pellmell. 53
The two men under the tree, two business-like Britishers, one of whom has a legal document in his hand. The Man in Beaver Hat enters to them. One of the two men says to him

"You'll pardon us, sir, for not going in with you, but..." BACK TO SCENE: He shudders a little, expressively. THE MA IN THE BEAVER HAT indicates the legal document without speaking. The jaunting cart with the gardener and maid driving pellmell in, around the driveway, toward rear of house. 55

Hibbs, the secretary, is giving some orders to the butler  Two or three other servants are present. Run a few feet. Then the rear door is flung open and Miss Smithson, the maid, comes excitedly in, starting at once to tell the secretary and butler what she saw at the Balfour House. T gardener follows. Suddenly all stop, tense, listening.

Sir James and chauffeur. The chauffeur is closing the doo depositing Sir James' bag on the floor as the butler come in. He is helping Sir James off with his coat as Hibbs, t secretary, comes in. The Butler takes the coat and bag an is about to start out with them when a ring is heard at t front door. The butler puts down the bag and coat and ope the front door, admitting the two agents seen under the tree at the Balfour house. Sir James at the door to the library, turns in some surprise. One of the agents, holdi up the lease, tells him:
"It's about a tenant, sir, for the old Balfour place." BACK TO SCENE: "A tenant?" Sir James is really surprised. He indicates for the two men to step into the library. Th do so, followed by Hibbs. 57
Sir James goes to desk and sits down. The agent hands him the lease. Hibbs stands at one side, in case he might be needed. Sir James unfolds the document. One of the agents says:
"I told him, sir, you'd make no repairs."

At desk, as the agent finishes title. Sir James nods that that was the right thing to do. Now, with the lease unfolded, he scans down it with a business-like eye. Suddenly he frowns, staring in astonishment down at the document.
Signature on lease:
Sir James, staring down at the signature. He looks up, hi lips forming the name: “Roger Balfour!" He looks up slowl Then, indicating the signature with a forefinger, he says slowly:
"This is the name of the man who committed suicide in that house five years ago!" BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title, in awe and wonder. 60
The two agents, staring in astonishment. 61
Hibbs, the secretary, as he says, involuntarily:
"Lucy's father!"
of group as they stare at each other. 63

"Tell Sir James an old friend -- just back from India -- has come  to visit him." BACK TO SCENE: Burke comes in; The butler closes the door and exits toward the library. 64

The group as before. The butler, stepping in from the entrance hall, gives Sir James the Message. “An old friend?" Sir James says, trying to recall who it might be and then, “Show him in." The butler exits. After a moment he returns with Burke. Sir James rises from the desk. The stand looking at each other for a moment, then Sir James comes forward and they greet each other with the warmth a cordiality of old friends long parted. Sir James then tur to the others and says:

of group as Sir James finishes title. The introduction is acknowledged with a bow, in which Burke allows his gaze t rest in rather long scrutiny on Hibbs, the secretary, so that the young man is beginning to be uncomfortable. Sir James and Burke, as Sir James tells him swiftly of th name signed to the lease. Burke smiles dryly and says:

Group as Burke finishes question. The two agents exchange look. Then one of them says:
“That's hard to say, sir. There was something weird about him -- that made you feel creepy --"
The two agents as the first one finishes title in awe. Th other one goes on:
“Something like he wasn't of this Earth.... something unholy--" BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title. The other nods in agreement to this. 69
Burke, looking out of scene at them for a moment with penetrating glance. Then he laughs and says:

Of group, as Burke finishes title, laughing. Sir James is now a bit more at ease, but still nervous and upset. The two agents look shamefaced and foolish. One of them gets over to Sir James and says that if they are not needed an more they'll be going. Sir James nods goodnight to them, turning and indicating to Hibbs to show them out. Hibbs exits with the two agents. Sir James sinks into his seat the desk. Burke draws up a chair. 71

Sir James and Burke at the desk as Burke sits down. Sir James stares for a moment, frowning at the signature on t lease. Then, with a sudden thought, he rummages in a draw of the desk and gets out a packet of papers. With nervous fingers, he slips the rubber band off and examines the signature attached. He places this beside the other and shows the two of them to Burke.

Two signatures, "Roger Balfour", along side each other. They very closely resemble each other.  BACK TO SCENE: The two men look up from the document seriously. For a moment, not a word is spoken between the Then Sir James says, in awe:
"The signatures are the same!" BACK TO SCENE: Burke nods solemnly. "Yes." 72

The room is dark, except for a shaft of moonlight from th window. In this moonlight, Lucy, pale and beautiful in a white dress, stands looking out into the garden. Hibbs enters to her. She does not turn for a moment. Hibbs stan looking at her for a moment, worried. Then he speaks to h softly. She turns, startled. Then, seeing it is Hibbs, sh says:

"I thought I heard a voice calling to me from the garden -- ever so softly: 'Lucy--'" BACK TO SCENE: Hibbs stares at her for a moment, then tur and looks out into the garden. He turns back to her, closing the casement window and tells her:
“There s no one there -- You're nervous, dear-
BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title. She smiles wanly. "Yes, I'm nervous." He turns and starts to close the windows. 73
Sir James and Burke, as Sir James talks to him, earnestly Burke, with a cynical smile, interrupts, saying:
"you mean a ghost, Sir James?" BACK TO SCENE: Sir James shakes his head, solemnly. They look at each other for a moment, then Sir James answers:
"Not a ghost, no! Worse than that--"

Sir James, finishes title, rises and takes down two or th ancient looking books from the bookcases that line the walls. He puts these on the desk, opens one of them, find @ passage and shows it to Burke. 75
Hibbs and Lucy, as Hibbs turns on a light switch by the door to hall and the room is flooded with light. They go over and sit down on a settee, as he talks to her serious 76

"We're not living in the Middle Ages, Sir James." CUT TO SCENE: Sir James is deeply thoughtful. He ponders this for a moment, then says:
"Just the same, I'd like to have a look at the vault where Roger Balfour was buried!" BACK TO SCENE. He finishes title. They sit looking at eac other solemnly.
A Newcomb shot, weird, eerie; bare-limbed, queer trees; i semi f.g. a mausoleum. Run a few feet for the effect and

The open door of the mausoleum. Sir James and Burke stagg backward out the door of the mausoleum. Burke has a pocke flashlight in his hand. He clicks it off. They stare at each other aghast. Then Sir James mutters, incredulously, in horror:
“The coffin was empty!" BACK TO SCENE: He finishes title. Burke nods slowly, solemnly. Suddenly Sir James clutches at Burke's arm and both men are tense, listening.

BACK TO INSERT: It closes beak. BACK TO SCENE: Sir James, trembling, gets over "Let's get out of here." Burke looks up and off, telling him: "It's only an owl." They turn to go.

The house and the ruined garden in weird lighting. At the gate stand the Man in the Beaver Hat, the girl in black with the sleeves that look like wings. These two are welcoming three others -- three men as queer in appearanc as the man in the Beaver Hat and his companion. Not a wor is spoken. The whole effect is odd, fantastic. They start toward the house, slowly, in solemn procession.

Vignetted passage of the printed page of an old book, the paper of a parchment-like quality, aged, the print in an Old English type: “--the undead, the vampyrs: dead bodies which leave their graves at night to suck the blood of the living."

Hibbs, Sir James and Burke. The Secretary is reading from one of the old books to the other two men. Both of whom seem to be profoundly impressed. He turns the page and is instantly struck by what he encounters there. He spreads the book open on the desk and calls their attention to i They lean over, seeing:

Sir James and Burke, looking down at the illustration. Burke looks up from it, in his eyes the faintest suggesti of a cynical smile. Sir James looks at the page facing th illustration and reads on for a few lines. There is a strange excitement in his manner as he indicates to Burke to read what he has just read. Burke looks down at the page:

Extract from book: "Men who have died by suicide frequently become vampyrs. They come out of their graves at night, rush upon people sleeping in their beds--" BACK TO SCENE: Burke looks up from the page. Sir James sa to him slowly, with deep significance:
"Roger Balfour died a suicide!"

"What was that?" BACK TO SCENE: They listen, tense, not moving a muscle. Suddenly Hibbs cries out:

They stop, looking around the room out of scene. Sir James cries out:
"Where's Lucy?" BACK TO SCENE: Taking a hand from her throat, Miss Smiths points wildly off saying:
"I -- locked her in there- BACK TO SCENE: Sir James and Hibbs rush out, Miss Smithso sinking into a chair. 89

Speaking comfortingly to her, he starts o with her toward an open window, out of scene. Hibbs looks off after them, deep concern in his eyes. 90

By open window. Sir James, leading in Lucy, seats her by the open window, leaning over her, speaking comfortingly her. In response to a question, she assures him that she all right. He looks up and off, as though spoken to out o scene. 91

Miss Smithson, fright in her eyes at the recollection of She gulps, then goes on:

at door. The vapor coming through the keyhole forms itsel into the shape of a man. The vapor slowly disappears and, standing there, is the Man in the Beaver Hat. He starts forward. Morning 142
